title: 106_s351
content: The Act may be cited as the "Taxpayer Oversight of Surplus Property Act". Congress acknowledges the importance of the Federal Personal Property Utilization and Donation Program in allocating surplus property to various eligible recipients, saving taxpayer dollars. Members of Congress and state/local officials are responsible for ensuring fair distribution and being accountable to taxpayers. The curr_chunk emphasizes the accountability of the Federal Government to American taxpayers regarding surplus property distribution. It highlights how State agencies have helped taxpayers acquire various surplus items. Additionally, it criticizes programs prioritizing foreign entities over the needs of American taxpayers. The curr_chunk emphasizes the need for new legislation to prioritize property transfers for domestic use over foreign assistance programs. The curr_chunk highlights the priority given to states and local organizations for receiving nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense. The amendment to Section 2547 of title 10, United States Code prioritizes providing nonlethal excess supplies from the Department of Defense to states and local governments before humanitarian relief purposes, with the President able to intervene in emergencies caused by natural disasters. The term 'State' in this subsection refers to various regions within the United States, including states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories. SEC. 4 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to allow for the transfer of property for environmental protection in foreign countries. The Administrator of General Services must determine that there are no Federal or State use requirements for the property under any other provision of law before the transfer can occur. Additionally, confiscated property can be transferred to foreign countries under this section. The Administrator of General Services will review statutes on disposal and donation of surplus personal property and submit a report to Congress within 180 days. The report will assess program effectiveness, property amounts, and types administered in fiscal years 1997 and 1998. Legislative recommendations will be made to consolidate programs under a single Federal authority working with State agencies.
